label.text: Water Pollution
Industrial wastewater is often discharged without treatment, causing pollution to soil, groundwater and seawater.
Biological, chemical, radioactive and thermal (heat) contaminants can make water unsafe for drinking or usage.
Industrial wastewater may contain metallic elements such as chromium, copper and zinc which are pollutants at higher concentrations.
The image shows industrial wastewater being discharged from a pipe.
Water Pollution

The sudden introduction of wastewater into a waterway can caused an increase in the amount of nitrogen in the water. Excess nitrogen can overstimulate the growth of organic matter (aquatic plants and algae).
When the amount of organic matter increases in waterways, the number of decomposers also increases. Decomposers consume large amounts of dissolved oxygen and release carbon dioxide into the water.
